PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All Questionnaires

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's records at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: Herbert Elsom
2. Your address: 2062 Toronto St., Regina
3. Date: Mar 24th, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Lobo Township, County of Middlesex, Ontario
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Andrew Elsom, farmer & various other work
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): Came to Moose Jaw, Mar 17-1898
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: My father & mother came to Canada from England in 1875 and came to South Ontario and a short while more out to Lobo township
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 22
9. What were your reasons for coming West?: My cousin F.W. Green who came out to the West some time in the 70s or 80s and had got into some trouble in stock & mix farming himself. Established in stock & mix farming himself. Established in stock & mix farming himself. Established in stock & mix farming himself.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):

The car and took after the stock we left Parkhill on Mar 10-1898 and arrived at Moose Jaw on Mar 17 and it was 40 below zero on that morning and about 5 feet deep snow and then was about 3 weeks of real winter weather after that. I went out to my uncle's place that night and the next morning I asked my uncle what his stable was and he said out there under that snow bank it was completely covered up and when there came a Chinook it melted and the snow was about 1 week and there was a fine crop that year.
Elson, Herbert
2062 Toronto St., Regina, 1952

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: Herbert Elsom
2. Your address: 2062 Toronto St., Regina
3. Date: Mar 24th, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   In the Township of County of Huddlesley, Ontario
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Andrew Elsom, farmer & various other occupations
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   Came to Montana March 1898
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   England, South Africa, and came to Western Canada. (You do not need to answer this question.)
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You may use "I was a small child")
   Answer: 22

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   They came because they heard about the gold rush in 1896 and had got word some time in 1897 that there was gold in Montana.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

The car and horse of Mr. Elsom were used to transport the family from Montana to Saskatchewan. The car was purchased by Mr. Elsom in 1900 and was used extensively during the winter months.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They did not think much of it.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Came up in a settler's car with stock.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.).

It was nice weather till we got to Lloydminster and then a blizzard came up and shield us off for 12 hrs.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I went 6 miles west of Moose Jaw and worked for my uncle all summer. Went back — the late fall or December.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Went down to the station to get a ticket to London, Ontario. I asked the agent how much was the ticket and he said $45.00. I asked him how much for a Return ticket and he said $45.00. Took a Return ticket but not knowing whether I would be back or not, but not knowing whether I was back before the ticket was used.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Worked on a farm and then learned the Blacksmith and wood working trade.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They did not think much of it.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

Came up in a settler car with others.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

It was very weather till we got to Calgary and then a Clyded came up and helped us off for $2.00.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures of the journey, conditions or other experiences)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I went 6 miles west of Moose Jaw and worked for Mr. White all summer.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

East from the Station & get a ticket & transfer to Ontario & paid the agent how much & got a return ticket and he said $45.00 so I took a return ticket and the weather would be better not but my memory was bad so I went back before the ticket was used.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How long did you stay?

Worked in a town and then started the Blacksmith and Wood working trade.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Every month

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married Anna Laura Sanders Sep 21st 1901

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Yes all our family came west before 4 or 5 years

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My father & mother, 5 sisters & one Brother all came in 4 or 5 years after I was settled here. Larry they are all passed on now all but my youngest sister and she lives in Roseburg Oregon USA

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Yes in the year 1899 I came back from Ontario and went to work for my cousin 6 miles west of Moose Jaw. He had bought a ¼ section of School Land and I was to start Breaking with 4 horses on a mule plow. I had just planted plow in a field the 1st set was one mile from his house and on the 3rd of May that it snowed 3 feet about 3 feet of snow and on the morning of the 5th of May

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

That soft snow that I rode on my bike over to find the horses and I thought it was the Great Bicycle Ride I had ever heard come a chinook and in three days the snow was all gone but oh the water there were lake of it
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, who?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

My father, mother, sisters, and brother have all came in 1875 from England by way of Liverpool. They are all buried on Kivalliq Bay by younger sisters and at River Road, Oregon USA

23. In the year 1899 I came back from Ontario and went to work for my cousin. He had bought 6 miles west of Murrayton. He had bought a 1/4 section of School Land away from Linton. Breaking with 4 horses in April the 1st, I shall have planted 20 acres in April the 1st, 3 acres mile from his house. Below is a list of crops:

- 1/4 of hay that I am buying on the homestead
- 5 acres of potatoes

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? By what means of travel?

That I do know that I wrote on my folks over there and the horses and I thought it was the best. I met Boyd Kroll and he was here from a cabin and in three days to the place was all gone but the water. There were lots of it.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1909

Have been living in Regina since 1918

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

Have been IOOF for 42 years
been through the Grand Patriotic today
and been & Sovereign Grand Lodge in Chicago
in 1943

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
34. Did many people move away during the 1920's? Did many return?

Have been living in Regina since 1918

35. If you or some member of your family have held public office or have been an organizer, chairman, etc., mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

36. If you or any of your family or friends were in the military to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobiles, organizing a fraternal lodge, etc.)

Have been 860 for 42 years
Len through A.F. & A.M. Frat. Lodge
and Lewis Brown Grand Roy - Chicago
in 1943

37. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) reason and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any charges in name; (5) the first name was given; (6) date and reason for change. 39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Have two daughters, one married here in Regina her husband is Sergeant in the Mounted Police, the other is married and lives in Ottawa, her husband is Col in the army headquarters in Ottawa, they have two sons oldest is going through for M.O.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

There are many and varied and more and coming all the time.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire. I have one cousin in my generation who is still alive and could give you more early data than I can and I know he would be delighted to do so. His name is Mr. George Green, 200 South Grovenor Ave.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:

Vancouver
